sections.heading: The Most Confusing Part of Japanese
sections.content:
Many learners struggle with は (wa) vs が (ga) because English doesn't make this distinction. Understanding this difference is crucial for natural Japanese.

Both can translate to the same English word , but they mark completely different things.

sections.heading: What is a Topic? (は)
sections.content:
The topic is what you're talking about - it sets the scene or context for your statement.

Think of は as saying: "Speaking of X..." or "As for X..."

私は学生です Watashi wa gakusei desu "As for me, (I) am a student" "Speaking of me, (I'm) a student"

sections.heading: What is a Subject? (が)
sections.content:
The subject is who/what performs the action or has the state described by the verb/adjective.

が emphasizes who/what specifically.

私が学生です Watashi ga gakusei desu "I am the one who is a student" (not someone else)

children.heading: With は (Topic)
children.content: 猫は好きです Neko wa suki desu "As for cats, (I) like them" (General statement about cats)

children.heading: With が (Subject)
children.content: 猫が好きです Neko ga suki desu "I like cats" / "It's cats that (I) like" (Specifying what you like)

children.heading: 1. General Statements
children.content: 犬は動物です "Dogs are animals" (General fact about dogs) 日本は美しいです "Japan is beautiful" (General statement)

children.heading: 2. Contrasting
children.content: 私は学生ですが、妹は会社員です "I am a student, but my sister is an office worker" (Contrasting two topics) 寿司は好きですが、刺身は嫌いです "I like sushi, but I dislike sashimi"

children.heading: 3. Known/Old Information
children.content: A: 田中さんはどこですか？ "Where is Tanaka?" B: 田中さんは図書館です "Tanaka is at the library" (Tanaka is already the topic)

children.heading: 4. Describing Topics
children.content: この本は面白いです "This book is interesting" (Describing the book) 東京は大きいです "Tokyo is big"

children.heading: 1. New Information
children.content: 誰が来ますか？ "Who is coming?" 田中さんが来ます "Tanaka is coming" (New information - answering who)

children.heading: 2. Existence Sentences
children.content: 机の上に本があります "There is a book on the desk" (が always used with ある/いる for existence) 部屋に猫がいます "There is a cat in the room"

children.heading: 3. Desires, Abilities, Potential
children.content:
水が欲しい "I want water" 日本語ができる "I can speak Japanese" 寿司が好き "I like sushi"

These always use が, not は.

children.heading: 4. Emphasis on Subject
children.content: 私が作りました "I made it" (emphasizing I did it) 雨が降っている "Rain is falling" (rain is the subject performing action)

children.heading: 5. Subordinate Clauses
children.content: 私が買った本 "The book that I bought" (が in relative clause) 彼が来たとき "When he came" (が in subordinate clause)

children.heading: は = Exhaustive/Contrastive
children.content: 象は鼻が長い "As for elephants, (their) trunks are long" (Implies: but other animals' aren't)

children.heading: が = Neutral Description
children.content: 象が鼻が長い "The elephant's trunk is long" (Just describing this elephant)

sections.heading: Double Particle Sentences
sections.content:
You can have both は and が in one sentence:

私は猫が好きです Watashi wa neko ga suki desu Topic Subject "As for me, cats are likeable" / "I like cats" 象は鼻が長い Zou wa hana ga nagai "As for elephants, trunks are long"

The topic sets the context, が marks the grammatical subject.

sections.heading: Question-Answer Patterns
sections.content: The particle in the question often determines the answer:

children.heading: Asking with は
children.content: Q: 田中さんは学生ですか？ "Is Tanaka a student?" A: はい、学生です "Yes, (he) is a student" (Confirming about the topic)

children.heading: Asking with が
children.content: Q: 誰が学生ですか？ "Who is a student?" A: 田中さんが学生です "Tanaka is a student" (Identifying the subject)

children.heading: With 好き/嫌い (like/dislike)
children.content: ✓ 寿司が好きです ✗ 寿司は好きです

children.heading: With できる (can do)
children.content: ✓ 日本語ができます ✗ 日本語はできます

children.heading: With 欲しい (want)
children.content: ✓ 水が欲しい ✗ 水は欲しい

children.heading: With ある/いる (exist)
children.content: ✓ 本があります ✗ 本はあります (When describing existence)

children.heading: With わかる (understand)
children.content: ✓ 意味がわかる ✗ 意味はわかる

sections.heading: Visual Summary
sections.content: は (wa) - TOPIC ├─ Sets context ├─ "Speaking of..." ├─ General statements ├─ Contrasts └─ Known information が (ga) - SUBJECT ├─ Who/what does action ├─ New information ├─ Answers "who/what" ├─ Existence (ある/いる) └─ Fixed patterns (好き, できる, etc.)

children.heading: Mistake 1: Using は with 好き
children.content: Wrong: 寿司は好きです ❌ Right: 寿司が好きです ✓

children.heading: Mistake 2: Using が for General Statements
children.content: Wrong: 犬が動物です ❌ (Unless answering "what is an animal?") Right: 犬は動物です ✓

children.heading: Mistake 3: Using は in Existence Sentences
children.content: Wrong: 本はあります ❌ Right: 本があります ✓

children.heading: Mistake 4: Not Answering with Matching Particle
children.content: Q: 誰が来ますか？ Wrong: 田中さんは来ます ❌ Right: 田中さんが来ます ✓

children.heading: Scenario 1: Introducing Yourself
children.content: ✓ 私は学生です "I am a student" (General self-introduction)

children.heading: Scenario 2: Someone Asks "Who's a Student?"
children.content: ✓ 私が学生です "I am (the one who is) a student" (Identifying yourself specifically)

children.heading: Scenario 3: Describing a Cat
children.content: ✓ この猫は白いです "This cat is white" (General description of known cat)

children.heading: Scenario 4: A Cat Appears
children.content: ✓ 猫がいます "There's a cat" (New information - existence)

children.heading: Scenario 5: Stating Preferences
children.content: ✓ コーヒーが好きですが、紅茶は好きじゃないです "I like coffee, but I don't like tea" (好き uses が, contrast uses は)

children.heading: は for Contrast (Implicit)
children.content: ビールは飲みます "(I) drink beer (but not other things)" (Implies contrast even without explicit second clause)

children.heading: が for Emphasis
children.content: 私が言いました "I said it" (emphasis: it was me) VS 私は言いました "I said it" (neutral: stating what I did)

sections.heading: Quick Decision Tree
sections.content: Choose particle: ├─ Is it existence (ある/いる)? → が ├─ Is it 好き/嫌い/できる/欲しい? → が ├─ Answering "who/what/which"? → が ├─ In subordinate clause? → が ├─ Setting context/topic? → は ├─ General statement? → は ├─ Contrasting? → は └─ Known information? → は

sections.heading: Key Differences Summary
sections.content: | Feature | は (Topic) | が (Subject) | | --------------- | ------------------- | ------------------ | | Function | Sets context | Identifies subject | | Translation | "As for..." | "X does/is" | | Use | General, known info | New, specific info | | Contrast | Yes | No | | Existence | No | Yes (ある/いる) | | 好き/できる | No | Yes |

sections.heading: Why This Matters
sections.content:
Misusing は/が changes meaning:

私は行きます "I will go" (neutral statement) 私が行きます "I will go" (emphasis: me, not others)

本は好きです "(I) like books (but maybe not magazines)" 本が好きです "(I) like books"

The nuance changes even if the core meaning is similar.

sections.heading: Key Takeaways
sections.content:
✓ は = sets topic, "speaking of X" ✓ が = marks subject, who/what does action ✓ Use が with 好き, できる, 欲しい, ある, いる ✓ Use は for general statements and contrast ✓ Match the particle when answering questions ✓ Both can appear in the same sentence

This distinction doesn't exist in English, so it takes practice. Focus on the common patterns first, and the nuances will become natural over time.
